- The buffer pool is organised into frames (size of database block, plus metadata) - Buffer metadata - Each frame in the buffer pool has these properties: Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - Pin co un t - number of current users of the block in that frame - D irty flag - 1 if the copy in the buffer has been changed (and needs to be properly written to the disk), 0 otherwise - Last access time - optional;used for LRU replacement - Lo ad time - optional;used for FIFO replacement - C lo ck flag - optional;used for clock replacement - Requesting a block (pseudocode) - if buffer pool already has a frame containing the block then increment pin count (‚Äúpin the block‚Äù) else if there is an empty frame then read block into frame and set pin count to 1 else choose a frame to be replaced (using chosen strategy) if dirty bit on the replacement frame is set then write block in replacement frame to disk en dif read requested block into replacement frame en dif en dif - Buffer replacement strategies - Let‚Äôs say you wanted to store a block in the buffer. - But the buffer is full! - We need to replace one of the existing frames with our new frame. - We can replace a frame if its pin count is 0 (basically, if nobody is using it). - But if we have multiple frames with pin counts of 0 (or multiple with 1), which do we pick? - We have several strategies for this: - LRU:select frame that has not been read or written for the longest time (you would need a table storing read and write times for frames, or use the ‚Äúlast access time‚Äù frame field) - FIFO:select the oldest frame (you would to use the ‚Äúload time‚Äù frame field) - C lo ck (Seco n d C han ce):approximation of LRU. The DBMS scrolls through all the frames in a cycle, and if it finds a frame that hasn‚Äôt been accessed in a full cycle it‚Äôll replace it. - What? You wanna go into more detail? - No problem! They all start at 0. - If a frame is being read or written to, the flag will become ‚Äò1‚Äô (note: the head doesn‚Äôt have to be on a frame to update its flag. The flag will just update whenever the frame is read/written). Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - The arrow won‚Äôt move until we need to search for a replacement frame. - Cool, so some frames have been acted upon and some haven‚Äôt. - When we need to replace a frame, the arrow will move clockwise looking for a 0-flag frame. - As we move, if the arrow finds a 1-flag frame, it‚Äôll change it to a 0 and continue. - If the arrow finds a 0-flag frame, it‚Äôll use that frame for replacement. - That‚Äôs it! - If all the frames are 1, that‚Äôs no problem;we‚Äôll just do a whole cycle of changing all the frames to 0, and then we‚Äôll end up replacing the frame we started with (last frame). - This reduces the need for a whole table (like in LRU) using simple 1-bit flags for each frame. - Sin gle bufferin g:only using a single buffer space 1. Process data in buffer 1 && Read B4 ‚Üí Buffer 2 - ... and so on. - If time to process a block > time to read a block: - Double buffer time = R + nP - Single buffer time = n(R + P) - Where - P = time to process a block Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - R = time to read a block - n = number of blocks - A good way to explain it is as follows (which is actually from wikipedia): - It is a nice sunny day and you have decided to get the paddling pool out, only you can not find your garden hose. - You'll have to fill the pool with buckets. - So you fill one bucket (or buffer) from the tap, turn the tap off, walk over to the pool, pour the water in, walk back to the tap to repeat the exercise. - This is analogous to single buffering. - The tap has to be turned off while you "process" the bucket of water. - Now consider how you would do it if you had two buckets. - You would fill the first bucket and then swap the second in under the running tap. - You then have the length of time it takes for the second bucket to fill in order to empty the first into the paddling pool. - When you return you can simply swap the buckets so that the first is now filling again, during which time you can empty the second into the pool. - This can be repeated until the pool is full. - It is clear to see that this technique will fill the pool far faster as there is much less time spent waiting, doing nothing, while buckets fill. - This is analogous to double buffering. - The tap can be on all the time and does not have to wait while the processing is done. The Five Minute Rule - The 5 Min ute Rule:data referenced every five minutes should be memory resident - Basically, if you‚Äôre fetching a piece of data at least every 5 minutes, you should keep that within memory so you don‚Äôt have to waste time fetching it. - It‚Äôs a rule of thumb;it‚Äôs not set in stone. - There‚Äôs a few calculations that were performed to get to this: - Assume a block is accessed every X seconds. Disk Organisation Data Items - How do we store different types of data? - Numbers: - Integer (short):we just store the binary equivalent - Real numbers:we use the IEEE 754 format (typically), with 1 bit sign, n bits mantissa and m bits exponent (mantissa and exponent are like a * 10b) - C haracters:we use coding schemes such as ASCII (1 byte) and UTF-8 (1-4 bytes) - B o o lean s:we use 1 byte per value, e.g. all 1‚Äôs for true and all 0‚Äôs for false - D ates: - Days since a given date (integer) from: - 1st Jan 1900 - 1st Jan 1970 (UNIX epoch) - ISO8601 dates: - Calendar dates:YYYYMMDD (8 characters) - Ordinal dates:YYYYDDD (7 characters) Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - Times: - Seconds since midnight (integer) - ISO8601 times: - HHMMSS (6 characters) - HHMMSSFF (8 characters, to represent fractional seconds) - Strin gs: - Null terminated (like in C) [E][C][S][\0][... - Length given [3][E][C][S][... - Fixed length [E][C][S] - B it arrays:Put the length first, then the bits (like length given for strings, but for bits instead) - Data items are either fixed or variable length, and may include what type of data it is so we know how to interpret them and what size they are (if they‚Äôre fixed) Records - Reco rds are collections of related data items, named fields. - For example, a user record with a username field, a password field and an email address field. - They can have fixed or variable formats and lengths. - For fixed format records, we have a schema that describes the format of the schema. - They describe: - Number of fields - Types of fields - Order in record - Meaning of each field - Example: - Schema: 1. e#, 2 byte integer 2. name, 10 byte char 3. dept, 2 byte code - Records: 5 5 s m i t h 0 2 8 3 j o n e s 0 1 - For variable format records, we can have a schema-less format. - What does that mean? - A block is a fixed-size unit of data (records or other data structures) that is used for storage and retrieval operations. - The size is determined by the underlying storage system. - Entire block can be read or written at once. - They‚Äôre like folders;you place records inside them. - The block header may contain: - File ID (or RELATION or DB ID) Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - This block ID - Record directory - Pointer to free space - Type of block (e.g. contains ‚Äútype x‚Äù records;is overflow, ‚Ä¶) - Pointer to other blocks ‚Äúlike it‚Äù - Timestamp - There are different things to consider when placing records into blocks: - Sep aratin g reco rds in a blo ck - How do you know when a record ends and when another begins? We split it up! - Split up records are sp an n ed. - However, we need pointers between partitions of the spanned records so we can follow a ‚Äúpath‚Äù and read the whole record. - Records that are not split up are un sp an n ed. - They‚Äôre simpler, but they may waste space. - Seq uen cin g - Ordering records in file (and block) by some key value - By sequencing we can make ordered reads more efficient and do merge-joins - You can either physically have records next to each other: - ... or you can have linked records, like a linked list: Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - You can also put a pointer to the overflow area in the header (especially useful for spanned records): - In directio n - How do we actually refer to the records? - There‚Äôs different options: - Physical addressin g - Just remember the physical location of the record and use that to locate the record when you need it - In direct addressin g - You use a record ID and a mapping (map table) from record IDs (logical db address) to physical db addresses - The physical address points to the block the record is in:this means the record can be moved around the block without changing its ID, and it‚Äôs still pretty fast. Tran slatio n Table - Used in addition to the map table (mapping of logical db addresses to physical db addresses) - A mapping of database addresses (either logical or physical) of items currently in memory (buffer pool) to their memory addresses (within buffer pool) - Used to check for references to items already in memory, before following the db address and going to disk Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - ‚ÄúNo swizzling‚Äù technique Po in ter Swizzlin g - For translating db addresses to memory addresses - Every block and record has two addresses: - A database address (when stored in disk) - A memory address (when stored in memory) - When you‚Äôre in the buffer (memory) it‚Äôs better to use memory addresses, otherwise you‚Äôll need to search the translation table each time. - Alright, so you‚Äôve got blocks and records and stuff in the database. - A ‚Äúmap‚Äù object points to some database addresses in blocks within secondary storage and we want to move it into the buffer (memory) so we can process it. - Well? Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - Uh... that‚Äôs great, but why are the arrows red? - Well, the pointers in that map are pointing to the database addresses of the blocks. - When we copied the map into the buffer, the pointers were still pointing to the database addresses instead of the new memory addresses! - When a pointer is pointing to a database address despite being in a map within the buffer, that pointer is swizzled (represented by red arrows in the illustrations). - When a pointer is pointing to a memory address in the buffer, that pointer is un swizzled (represented by green arrows in the illustrations). - We want our pointers to be unswizzled! - To unswizzle these pointers, we‚Äôre going to have to convert the block 1 pointer from a database address to a memory address using some kind of translation table. - However, the next pointer is pointing to a block that isn‚Äôt within memory. What do we do? - We can just load block 2 into memory. - Now our pointers are unswizzled! - There are a couple of swizzling strategies: - A uto matic:as soon as a block is brought into memory, locate all pointers and unswizzle them all - On D eman d:only unswizzle a pointer when we actually look it up Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - No swizzlin g:don‚Äôt unswizzle at all;just use the translation table on demand (kind of hard to call this a swizzling strategy if it doesn‚Äôt swizzle) - This also works the other way around. - When blocks are written back to the disk, swizzled pointers are rewritten using the translation table. - You also need to beware of pinned blocks (that cannot yet be safely written to disk) - Other o p tio n s in -between - Trade-off between: - Flexibility (easier to move records on insertion / deletion) - Cost (of maintaining indirection) Insertion and Deletion - So, we‚Äôve talked about storing records in blocks and accessing them. - But what about inserting records and deleting records? - Let‚Äôs start with insertion. - If the records do not have any kind of order, it‚Äôs simple. - To insert without order, either: 1. Look for the next empty slot 2. Just stick it at the end Computer Science / Software Engineering Notes Network - If we need to keep some fixed order, such as sorted by primary key, things get a bit trickier. - First, we find the block we want to put the record in. - Then, if we find some space to put the record, we need to shift the records around so we can put the new record in its proper place. - However, records can be quite big. Do we really want to shift those huge, hefty records every time we want to insert? - We don‚Äôt have to! We can use an o ffset table. - An offset table is a group of pointers that point to records in a block. - Basically, we can store the order of the records in the offset table instead of the physical location of the records themselves.
